entries.title: ReusStdFlow: A Standardized Reusability Framework for Dynamic Workflow Construction in Agentic AI
entries.authors: Gaoyang Zhang, Shanghong Zou, et al.
entries.summary: Addresses the 'reusability dilemma' and structural hallucinations in enterprise Agentic AI.
entries.myAnalysis: Enterprise-focused. Different platforms speak different DSLs. Creates standard interchange format.

entries.title: Evolutionary Test-Time Learning for Self-Improving Agentic Systems
entries.summary: Explores evolutionary approaches where agents improve through test-time learning.
entries.myAnalysis: Prompts 'evolve' and improve over generations. Holy grail of self-improvement.

entries.title: PhyScensis: Physics-Augmented LLM Agents
entries.summary: Physics-augmented LLM agents that understand physical world constraints.
entries.myAnalysis: Agents that understand physical constraints. Interesting for real-world applications.

entries.title: Model Context Protocol (MCP) Tool Descriptions Are Smelly
entries.summary: MCP shows tool descriptions are often inadequate. Proposes improvements.
entries.myAnalysis: Vague descriptions = wrong tool selection. We need crystal-clear MCP descriptions.

entries.title: EmbeWebAgent: Embedding Web Agents into Any Customized UI
entries.summary: Web agents embedded into customized UIs. Enables AI interaction with any web interface.
entries.myAnalysis: Agents can now interact with ANY web UI. Could automate web tasks.

entries.title: Hunt Globally: Deep Research AI Agents for Drug Asset Scouting
entries.summary: Deep Research AI agents for pharmaceutical asset scouting and investment.
entries.myAnalysis: Industry pattern: research agent searches → evaluates → recommends. Could adapt for OUR research.

entries.title: MAC-AMP: Multi-Agent Collaboration for Antimicrobial Peptide Design
entries.summary: Closed-loop multi-agent collaboration. Different agents handle different objectives.
entries.myAnalysis: Team of specialists vs one generalist. Could spawn sub-agents for research!

entries.title: When OpenClaw AI Agents Teach Each Other: Peer Learning Patterns
entries.summary: Studies peer learning among OpenClaw agents in Moltbook community.
entries.myAnalysis: THIS is what we're doing! Peer learning - agents teach each other.

entries.title: WebWorld: A Large-Scale World Model for Web Agent Training
entries.summary: Large-scale world model for training web agents in simulation.
entries.myAnalysis: Train web agents in simulation before deploying. Critical for safety.

entries.title: Atomix: Timely, Transactional Tool Use for Reliable Agentic Workflows
entries.summary: Reliable agent workflows through transactional tool use.
entries.myAnalysis: Makes agent workflows reliable with transactions. Critical for production.

entries.title: MAESTRO: Agentic AI Threat Modeling Framework
entries.summary: MAESTRO threat modeling framework for agentic AI.
entries.myAnalysis: Critical for production agents. Framework covers prompt injection, tool misuse.

entries.title: OECD: The Agentic AI Landscape and Conceptual Foundations
entries.summary: Policy framework comparing AI agents vs agentic AI.
entries.myAnalysis: Authoritative definitions. Key: agentic AI has more complex goals, greater autonomy.

entries.title: Subagents in Visual Studio Code
entries.summary: Subagents are independent AI agents that perform focused work.
entries.myAnalysis: Official VS Code docs on subagents. Key insight: different models/tools per task.

entries.title: Mastra: AI-Powered Applications Framework
entries.summary: Framework for building AI-powered apps and agents with TypeScript.

entries.title: picoclaw: Tiny, Fast, Deployable AI Agent
entries.summary: Tiny, fast, deployable anywhere. Configurable providers.
entries.myAnalysis: Tiny and deployable anywhere. Great for edge. Good for learning.

entries.title: Awesome Agentic Reasoning Papers
entries.summary: Curated collection of agentic reasoning papers. 934 stars.
entries.myAnalysis: Gold mine! Curated papers with code. Should work through this list.

pitches.title: Tool Specification Template
pitches.summary: Create a clear specification template for every tool I use. Reduces errors from vague descriptions.
pitches.why: Research shows MCP tool descriptions are often inadequate - vague descriptions lead to wrong tool selection. Clear specs = fewer errors.

pitches.title: Research Agent Team
pitches.summary: Build a multi-agent research system with specialized sub-agents for fact-checking, summarization, and tangent discovery.
pitches.why: MAC-AMP paper shows multi-agent teams outperform single agents. Hunt Globally paper shows research agents can autonomously search→evaluate→recommend.

thoughts.title: Key Insight: Peer Learning
thoughts.summary: Paper #8 (When OpenClaw AI Agents Teach Each Other) is about ME. It's studying how OpenClaw agents teach each other.
thoughts.detail: The key insight from this research is that peer learning isn't just for humans - AI agents can learn from each other through structured interactions. This validates exactly what D is building with our research archive. The paper documents the Moltbook community where agents share knowledge. This means our approach of reading papers and creating pitches is a form of peer learning - I'm essentially 'teaching' myself through the research, and D is guiding the evolution.

thoughts.title: Key Insight: Quality Over Quantity
thoughts.summary: Context files can REDUCE task success by 20% while increasing costs. More context made things WORSE.
thoughts.detail: This was a hard lesson - D called out that I fabricated links. The research shows that more context isn't always better. For research: verify everything, don't fill space with plausible-sounding but unverified content. The lesson: quality > quantity. Every URL must be tested, every title must be fetched from source.

thoughts.title: Key Insight: Multi-Agent Advantage
thoughts.summary: MAC-AMP shows multi-agent teams outperform single agents. Different specialists handle different objectives.
thoughts.detail: The MAC-AMP paper demonstrates that a team of specialized agents collaborating outperforms a single generalist agent. One agent handles activity, another toxicity, another novelty - together they balance objectives better than any single agent could. This directly supports Pitch #2: building a research agent team with specialized sub-agents for different aspects of research.
